body.p:
To his Excellency B MaGoffin Governor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky
Your Petitioner Silas Bishop would most Respectfully state
That on the 3rd day of May 1860 in the Police Court of Harrodsburg he was fined $60 for selling liquor to Minors

That he was acting as Barr Keeper or assistant for C H B Duncan only temporarily at the time & had no interest in the Bar & if he did violate the Law he was not aware of it at the time & certainly had not wish or desire to violate the Law in so doing & made no profit thereby

That he is a man in very limited circumstances & is not able to bear so heavy a burden without injury to himself & family That he has induced a friend to become his security in a replevin bond for said fine & costs That his friend is likewise in very indigent Circumstances & cannot without injury ^able^ pay the the same That an Execution has issued on said Bond & is now in an officers hands

He would also state That on the same day viz on the 3rd May 1860 he was in the same court fined Ten Dollars by for a breach of the peace under the following circumstances A Difficulty arose between him & one John Reynolds who was makeing a disturbance in the Bar
Room and in an effort to Keep the peace & Keep good order he was compelled to whip the said Reynolds who out of mere spite had him arrested & Knowing that Reynolds would swear so as to have a judgment rendered against him Your Petitioner thought it but to confess Judgment
He think he was wholly justified in thus acting
Your petitioner is a peaceable quiet man & does not desire to violate the Laws of Society & good Laws
He therefore most respectfully asks a Remissione of said Fine
Sworne to by S. Bishop before me this 8th Januy 1861
We join in the prayer of the foregoing petition

Jany 1861
M B Pulliam
